This so-called attempt to "save the internet" is a gift to edge providers who want to market personal data. GOP members have introduced three bills that would protect consumers without government involvement ‚Äì let‚Äôs focus our attention on those practical solutions instead.

This isn‚Äôt the first time we‚Äôve debated net neutrality. When Trump first announced he was repealing regulations, liberals wouldn't stop talking about how this would radically change the internet as we knew it. But when the regulations ceased, these doomsday predictions fell flat.

I support the bipartisan and commonsense "bright line" rules for net neutrality ‚Äì no blocking, no throttling and no paid prioritization ‚Äì that protect consumers, but the Save the Internet Act reaches far beyond these commonsense protections.

The internet isn‚Äôt broken, so why are liberals trying to fix it? In H.R. 1644, House Democrats want to give federal entities nearly unlimited authority to regulate the internet, which is why I voted against it.
